article_title: Texas ranks last in U.S. in nursing home care
article_text:
Texas ranks last in U.S. in nursing home care

Photo: RICARDO B. BRAZZIELL, MBO State Sen. Charles Schwertner, R-Georgetown, has sponsored...

As a tough nursing home licensing bill moved through the Legislature in Austin, elder care officials and advocates for the elderly expressed concern Thursday after a new analysis of federal data showed that Texas has the largest share of low-rated nursing homes in the nation.

article_metadata.description: Fifty-one percent of the state's 1,193 nursing homes that receive Medicare or Medicaid earned only one or two stars out of a five-star rating system, the Kaiser Family Foundation found when looking at the Nursing Home Compare database compiled by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.  The star ratings, similar to those found in restaurants and hotels, offer a shorthand way to measure staffing and quality while taking into account deficiencies in care or safety issues uncovered during inspections.  "Considering the most frail and vulnerable citizens in our country are living in nursing homes, this research shines the light on the important issue of nursing home quality," Cristina Boccuti, a senior associate at the foundation and co-author of the report, said Thursday.  "For some, it means choosing between quality care and a nursing home in their local community," said Patty Ducayet, long-term care ombudsman at the Department of Aging and Disability Services.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam
